title: Where’s Emma?
text: Hey! Welcome to my travel blog. My name is Emma Burke and I am currently a graduating senior at UCSB, studying Environmental Science. Despite knowing that planes are terrible for the environment, I absolutely love travelling. I am so grateful for all the opportunities I have had to travel and I thank my parents for taking me on trips and sparking my curiosity to explore new places. This website is essentially an online photo album for myself and family and friends.

title: Backstory
text:
This is a place where I will tell the story of “Wheres Emma?”
That question became a running joke in my family because when I was just born, the first thing my older sister would do was ask “Wheres Emma?!” as soon as she got home from preschool. As an infant, I was usually located within the confines of the household, usually stationary, limited to wherever my parents would carry me.
Nowadays, both my sister and my parents are unconcerned with my whereabouts. Just this past winter I told them I was going to Brazil and they didn’t bat an eye or ask any further questions. It is up to me now to answer the unasked question of “Where’s Emma?”

When I was seven years old my family decided it would be a good time to take me and my sister on a five week trip to Thailand with our Grandmother who grew up there. While I wish I was a little older to remember everything, this trip really stuck with me. I think the vastly different climate and culture made a lasting impression. It was the most incredible journey I had experienced.

As I got older and gained independence, I started traveling with friends. When I was 13 I went to England with my two best friends and we exercised our independence and autonomy, navigating trains and buses to explore the country (and staying with my friend Daisy’s grandparents of course.) Later on I signed up for a youth educational trip to take me back to Thailand and Vietnam, where I met my distant relatives on my Grandmother’s side. There I studied access to education in rural settings.
Two years later I did another trip to the Dominican Republic to study public health. This was the first country I went to where I could practice speaking Spanish.
My Spanish skills were cemented when I studied abroad in Chile for three months. It was a wonderful educational experience and the most academically engaged I have ever been.

After studying abroad I decided to go on a long trip through Uruguay and Brazil with my friends. We already had experience traveling together in Mexico, so we were ready for another big adventure.

Since being in College, I have been to Mexico, Hawaii, Uruguay, Brazil, and Puerto Rico with a variety of friends. I have learned a lot from traveling with friends. I have gotten to see them pushed to their limits and tested in new settings with new challenges. Sometimes friendships faltered after long exhaustive travel, other times they were strengthened. In any case, I am confident enough in my travel experiences and my language abilities that I am ready to travel alone.

Where will I go next?

title: Study Abroad
text:
In the fall of 2023, I studied abroad in Chile. The program was titled “Socio-Ecological Sustainability” and our classes focused on conservation strategies and ethics, and the intersection of culture and environment. Attending this program was such a privilege, especially because we were able to go on so many field trips out in nature, conduct our own research, and meet and talk with Indigenous Mapuche people. Below I will attach some of my work that I completed while I was abroad:
Opinion Editorial on Social Perceptions of Conservation Approaches
Paper on Forest Conservation Strategy
Ethnographic Report of Villarrica - Relationships to Medicinal Plants
One of the most special things we did on our program was conduct our own research project in groups. My group chose to study community gardens. We had the opportunity to interview 5 Mapuche women who owned and tended their own land and gardens in the region. This is our final report:
Sustaining the Work: Community Gardens in the Tolten River Basin



Me and Sally helping mix a soil amendment product via a japanese process called “Bokashi” The Mapuche women who own the farm learned Bokashi in a garden education workshop in the region.



Eliza taking notes on the Bokashi process. Allison, one of the sisters who owns the farm, preparing an ingredient for the Bokashi.










Allisons hands and Elizabeth, the other sister, hosting us with a homemade meal after making the Bokashi pile.

title: Solo Journeys
text:
Here I am going to document my not-so-solo travels that were sponsored by Rustic Pathways, a company that leads youth trips either for tourism or community service or educational purposes. My trip to Vietnam and Thailand was focused on studying access to education. The trip to the Dominican Republic was focused on public health. Both trips were great experiences.

title: My Travels
text: I have been very fortunate and very privileged to have had so many opportunities to travel. I am eternally grateful to my parents who brought me as a young child on many trips, sparking my desire to explore the world and other cultures.
